facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 598 of 2007 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPEAL NO. 598 OF 2007 K. MATHUR, J. This appeal is directed against the order dated 6.12.2006 passed by the learned Single Judge of the Kerala High Court whereby the learned Single Judge has rejected the election petition filed by the appellant on the preliminary objection raised by the respondent that affidavit in form No.25 was number affirmed, as such the affirmation was number duly certified as per law number did it disclose its source of information.

facts.text: Election held on 29.4.2006 to Kerala Legislative Assembly from No.67 Kodungalloor Assembly Constituency.

anchor.surface_text: Brief facts which are necessary for disposal of this appeal are that an election was held on 29.4.2006 to the Kerala Legislative Assembly from No.67 Kodungalloor Assembly Constituency. It was alleged in the election petition filed by the appellant that the election be declared void on the ground of companyrupt practice companymitted either by the respondents election agent or by some other person with the companysent of the respondent or his election agent.

facts.text: Appellant filed election petition alleging corrupt practice committed by respondent's election agent or others with consent.

anchor.surface_text: It was alleged in the election petition filed by the appellant that the election be declared void on the ground of companyrupt practice companymitted either by the respondents election agent or by some other person with the companysent of the respondent or his election agent. The election petition was registered and numberice was issued.

facts.text: Respondent was the elected candidate.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was the elected candidate and he raised a preliminary objection on the maintainability of the election petition.

facts.text: Respondent raised preliminary objections including that affidavit in Form 25 was not affirmed, not certified, no source of information, verification defective, allegations vague.

holdings.text: The verification of the election petition is substantially compliant and the phraseology conveys the same meaning; the view of the Single Judge is not agreed with.

anchor.surface_text: After going through the affidavit filed by the appellant and the format of the companycluding portion of the affidavit, we fail to appreciate that in what way the verification can be found to be bad except that it has number used the word, true it is expressed in other way, numberpart thereof is false and numberhing which is relevant has been companycealed. Instead of saying, true it has been put up in other way round,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Equivalent phrasing ('no part false, nothing concealed') to required CPC verification; substance and essence conveyed; not a major defect warranting rejection under S86.

holdings.text: The defect in the affidavit is of very minor nature and does not go to the root of the matter.

anchor.surface_text: Here also the defect as pointed out by learned Single Judge was that the appellant had number signed and affirmed in the manner inasmuch as there is number certification of the Notary that it was solemnly affirmed by the appellant before him. This objection was based on the fact that after the signature of the deponent the only words occurring before the signature of the Notary are, Before me.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Minor placement issue in notary certification still conveys solemn affirmation; bona fide mistake, curable, not fatal to petition constitution.

holdings.text: Defects pointed out do not entail dismissal under Section 86 as they do not relate to Sections 81, 82 or 117; no defect of this nature warrants dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: Section 86 says that the High Court shall dismiss the election petition which does number companyply with the provisions of Section 81 of Section 82 or Section 117. But number of defect of the nature as pointed out by the respondent would entail dismissal of the election petition.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S86 limited to specific sections; S83 defects, if minor, cosmetic not going to root; petition not to be summarily dismissed on technicalities.

holdings.text: Even if defects construed serious, court must issue notice and give opportunity to cure before dismissal under O6 R17 or O7 R11 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: the Court should give proper opportunity to cure the defects and in case of failure to remove cure the defects, it companyld result into dismissal on account of Order 6 Rule 17 or Order 7 Rule 11 CPC.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural fairness requires opportunity to amend/rectify; no dismissal at threshold without notice; supported by precedents like Murarka Radhey Shyam.

holdings.text: The defects are cosmetic and do not go to the root; Single Judge's order set aside and matter remitted for proceeding with election petition.

anchor.surface_text: Both the defects which have been pointed out by learned Single Judge were too innocuous to have resulted in dismissal of the election petition on the basis of the preliminary objection. The Courts have to view it whether the objections go to the root of the matter or they are only companymetic in nature.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Objections cosmetic; strict construction but no summary dismissal; remit for trial on merits.

holdings.text: View taken by Single Judge incorrect; order dated 6.12.2006 set aside and matter remitted to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: the view taken by learned Single Judge of the High Court is number companyrect and we set aside the order dated 6.12.2006 passed by the learned Single Judge in P.No.6 of 2006 and remit this matter back to the High Court of Kerala for proceeding with the election petition of the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative findings on defects minor/curable lead to reversal of dismissal.

precedents.citation: Murarka Radhey Shyam Ram Kumar v. Roop Singh Rathore Ors.  1964 3 SCR 573

anchor.surface_text: Murarka Radhey Shyam Ram Kumar v. Roop Singh Rathore Ors.  1964 3 SCR 573

precedents.case_name: Murarka Radhey Shyam Ram Kumar v. Roop Singh Rathore
precedents.cited_proposition: defect in the verification due to inexperience of the Oaths Commissioner is such a fatal defect as to require the dismissal of the election petition
precedents.cited_holding: We agree with the view expressed by the Election Tribunal and we do not think that the defect in the verification due to inexperience of the Oaths Commissioner is such a fatal defect as to require the dismissal of the election petition

precedents.citation: H.D.Revanna v. G.Puttaswamy Gowda Ors.  1999  2 SCC 217

anchor.surface_text: H.D.Revanna v. G.Puttaswamy Gowda Ors.  1999  2 SCC 217

precedents.case_name: H.D. Revanna v. G. Puttaswamy Gowda
precedents.cited_proposition: non-compliance with Section 83 does not lead to dismissal under Section 86; defect in verification of the election petition or the affidavit accompanying the election petition has been held to be curable and not fatal
precedents.cited_holding: Significantly, Section 86 does not refer to Section 83 and non-compliance with Section 83 does not lead to dismissal under Section 86. ... Defect in verification ... curable and not fatal

precedents.citation: Sardar Harcharan Singh Brar v. Sukh Darshan Singh Ors.  2004  11 SCC 196

anchor.surface_text: Sardar Harcharan Singh Brar v. Sukh Darshan Singh Ors.  2004  11 SCC 196

precedents.case_name: Sardar Harcharan Singh Brar v. Sukh Darshan Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: deficiency in particulars could not have been a ground for dismissing the petition at the threshold; Section 86 contemplates dismissal but does not cover non-compliance of Section 83
precedents.cited_holding: deficiency in particulars could not have been a ground for dismissing the petition at the threshold

precedents.citation: Azhar Hussain v. Rajiv Gandhi 1986  Supp. SCC 315

anchor.surface_text: Azhar Hussain v. Rajiv Gandhi 1986  Supp. SCC 315

precedents.cited_proposition: election petition could be summarily dismissed under Order 6 Rule 16 and Order 7 Rule 11 CPC for failure to furnish material facts and particulars essential for cause of action
precedents.cited_holding: though Section 83 is not mentioned in Section 86, but ... dismissal ... on account of failure of compliance of Order 6 Rule 16 and Order 7 Rule 11, CPC

precedents.citation: Chandrakant Uttam Chodankar v. Dayanand Rayu Mandrakar Ors.  2005  2 SCC 188

anchor.surface_text: Chandrakant Uttam Chodankar v. Dayanand Rayu Mandrakar Ors.  2005  2 SCC 188

precedents.case_name: Chandrakant Uttam Chodankar v. Dayanand Rayu Mandrakar
precedents.cited_proposition: where the defects in copies were curable non-vital in nature the election petition cannot be dismissed at the threshold for non-compliance with Section 81(3)
precedents.cited_holding: where the defects in copies were curable non-vital in nature the election petition cannot be dismissed at the threshold

precedents.citation: Ram Prasad Sarma v. Mani Kumar Subba Ors. Etc.  2003  1 SCC 289

anchor.surface_text: Ram Prasad Sarma v. Mani Kumar Subba Ors. Etc.  2003  1 SCC 289

precedents.case_name: Ram Prasad Sarma v. Mani Kumar Subba
precedents.cited_proposition: verification in support of the allegations of corrupt practice accompanying the petition by Oath Commissioner was not integral part of the petition; mere absence of stamp and name not vital
precedents.cited_holding: Mere absence of the stamp and name of Oath Commissioner ... would not amount to vital or material deviation

precedents.case_name: R.P. Moidutty v. P.T. Kunju Mohammad
precedents.cited_proposition: defect of verification is not fatal, it can be cured; but if petitioner persists without curing, petition cannot be tried
precedents.cited_holding: the defect of verification is not fatal to the petition, it can be cured ... However, the petitioner persisted in pursuing the petition without proper verification which the petitioner should not have been permitted to do
